review: I‚Äôve been wanting to get into programming a little so i downloaded a few similar apps and ran thru a few of their modules.  Within maybe 10-15 minutes, I would exhaust their free content and would be pressed to upgrade to a pro account to learn any more. I thought about doing it for one of the apps even though the language i was looking for (C#) wasnt available yet.  Then I found this app and my search is over!  It does have a pro version like the rest, but it doesnt appear to hold back content from non pro members.  It also has waaaaay more content to dive into compared to the others.  I love that in addition to the learning/ module side, there is also a challenge mode that turns a tough subject into a game.  Then SoloLearn takes it a step further and lets users share codes they‚Äôve been working on INSIDE THE APP and you can run them on your phone to check out how they work.  This is awesome and is going to keep me hooked for a while!
title: Tried a few, this is the one!

review:
Okay, so I guess the reading portions of the lessons are free, which is nice, but most people learn by doing. I hadn't even gotten through the third Javascript lesson yet before I got an alert saying that I'd run out of free practice. You could say just to go to my PC where there are more free resources available, but if I was readily able to do that, I wouldn't have bothered to find an app to help me learn. I have an infant who wants to be held at all times (and doesn't seem to like my office chair), and a requirement to learn Javascript for my job, so an app is how I'm attempting to make both work.
Don't get me wrong, I'm a big believer in supporting the developers of apps that serve me well, and this app does look like it *might* be quite helpful to me. It's just hard to properly rate an app's usefulness when some of what I find to be essential parts of it are locked behind a paywall, so I don't know if I can properly evaluate it for purchase. While I know that there's a free trial, I know that I will be auto-charged upon that trial's expiration, and I don't know if I'll want to pay yet. I'd be okay with the free trial if it didn't involve consenting to pay upfront, rather than waiting until the trial's conclusion to ask me about it.

review: SoloLearn is fantastic.  I have taken their online courses in C++, Java, HTML, CSS, PHP, JavaScript, SQL, Python, C, and C#, I am now in the middle of their Data Science with Python course, and I plan to take their Machine Learning  course next.  All the courses I have taken have been really fun and instructive.  Of course you will need a lot of experience beyond the courses before you can really consider yourself to have meaningful coding skills, but the courses will give you a great start, and the community and coding challenges will help you test, practice, and develop the skills taught in the courses.  Last but not least, SoloLearn has a large, active, and devoted community of friendly, helpful, and supportive users.  You will learn a great deal from reading the comments of your fellow students, asking questions, and trying to help answer the questions of others, and you will make new online friends of all ages and backgrounds from all over the world.

review:
I got this app because I wanted to brush up on some old skills and learn new coding languages, and it‚Äôs been well worth my while. I‚Äôve taken courses in university, Pluralsight, MVA, etc., and this app has content on par with the best of them, not a simple 'Hello, world' playground. The lessons are expertly written and the app, itself, makes exploration a breeze.

You can very quickly gain advanced and expert knowledge in one of the available languages, then put your knowledge to the test in innumerable challenges. People in the range of novice to intermediate will gain the most, as expected, but even very experienced coders are likely to learn some things from the courses.

review:
I do understand that the common mobile app strategy is to have pop up ads come while using the app to push users to buy the pro version, but that does not work for SoloLearn. Interrupting me every section (especially with four questions) to see an ad was a huge turnoff for me and I‚Äôve lost interest in even wanting to spend money here. And I‚Äôve been a learner since 2019.

My suggestion: rewrite the structure of the curriculum entirely, cutoff the lesson to one unit for the free version or find another way to interject ads. Whoever made that decision to do ads like that is not good in stakeholder engagement.

review:
This is a self-paced learning system with practice exercises that are essentially canned solutions with no constructive feedback from monitors. It‚Äôs useful to compare this app with Khan Academy or Brilliant; both provide explicit feedback on exercises, and have help and ‚Äúcontact us‚Äù options. This app does not. It relies on ‚Äúchat‚Äù pages which are a chaotic mix of users, in multiple languages essentially firing off random posts and solutions.

Cynically, this is a demo of how to make money designing and launching an app and then sitting back and collecting revenue, without really having to expend any time in actually running a teaching program.

review: I was previously using this app quite a bit and found it to work out quite well as a free app to learn a coding language(in my case c#) but then they added one of those heart systems that don‚Äôt let you use the app after you lose them. So now I‚Äôm limited to 3 mistakes and each heart takes 5 hours to refill. So much for doing some actual learning because now I just can‚Äôt make mistakes‚Ä¶ which in my experience is a large part of the learning process.
title: Heart system
developerResponse:
{'id': 33019416, 'body': 'Hi,

Thanks for your feedback!

If you‚Äôre a Free plan user, you start each day with a full set of Hearts, which you need to complete lessons. Hearts encourage you to pay close attention to the lesson theory ‚Äî get a quiz question wrong, and you‚Äôll lose a Heart. Lose all your Hearts and you‚Äôll need to wait for them to refill before you can access lesson content. Hearts take a few hours to refill, so while you wait you can carry on exploring everything on offer in the rest of the Sololearn app and connect with other Sololearners. Code Challenge, anyone?

If you‚Äôre eager to carry on with your lesson, you can upgrade to PRO for unlimited Hearts or buy more Hearts using your Bits.

Happy Sololearning!', 'modified': '2022-11-07T13:28:38Z'}

review:
The previous app (‚ÄúLearn Python‚Äù) did not require an email address. When the developer came out with the new Solo Learn (this app), the old app ‚ÄúLearn Python‚Äù STOPPED working. The app is also no longer available in the App Store, so you cannot reinstall.

Account creation (requiring email address) should be optional, not enforced. Some users do NOT need an account because of security reason. E.g. how secure is Solo Learn server? What is their server got hacked? Now the bad guy have your email address and password.

 If you believe that you have a valid case for an exception to our no-refund policy, please contact Sololearn Support by providing feedback from the app/website or emailing info@sololearn.com.

review:
Not gonna dwell on praises, except to say that the app and the website are the best, and pro is worth it.

One day I downloaded this app and taught myself Python, and now I‚Äôm working in aerospace, coding in many languages including Python. This app has your bases covered. One day at work I suddenly had to learn C, and this app had it. Then I had to learn C++ and this app had it. Then Java, then web development, and this app had it. It even has tutorials for tools like git, and concepts like cryptography.

You won‚Äôt become a pro in any area with the app alone, but you‚Äôll get the tools you need to make your ideas a reality.

A computer is like a free brain, you can use to think about and remember things you don‚Äôt feel like thinking about and remembering. A computer is not unlike having your own personal ‚ÄúRain Man‚Äù... except this rain man does exactly what you tell him 100% of the time, even to your own demise, and he can telepathically communicate with other rain men.

With programming, you can automate any process, all the way down to the typing and clicking you do as a user (which is why you have to tell websites you‚Äôre not a robot). Find yourself in a loop of repeatedly clicking and dragging and typing? All in the same pattern? You can automate it. 

If something is boring and easy, you can automate it. Therefore, by definition, programming is always challenging. For me, it is a deeply satisfying challenge, which is why I made a career out of it. And this app has been a valuable resource.

review:
UPDATED REVIEW:
The developer seemed to have fixed whatever the ad issue was that I and several other reviewers pointed out. (Original review is below this one)

The only thing I find kind of odd is that the developer doesn‚Äôt actually publicly acknowledge the ad issue, just tells you to contact support. To what end? The issue is obvious?

Regardless of the obvious misstep by SoloLearn support in responding to reviews. As I stated in my original review, the app is quite good. I‚Äôve used it a lot over the past several months and there‚Äôs a lot to like and it works fantastically as a means to support other more thorough learning methods (videos, books, mentors, etc.)

I definitely recommend the app as someone looking to add a mobile resource to their learning routine. 

My main suggestion to the developer is to give more time on the challenges and require the authors of the questions to add descriptions and explanations to help aid learning and not just offer competition. 

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
The newest update added a pretty awful feature. 

Ads that can‚Äôt be closed or skipped. You sit there looking at the ad thinking it‚Äôll close in 30 seconds or so like every other free app... but no, you can sit there until the zombie apocalypse, it will never close. 

So now I get to force close the app every time I complete a section. 

All kidding aside...
I will 100% return and update this review to 5 stars when this unacceptable bug is fixed as the content and usability of the rest of the app is amazing.

review:
1) Have no ability to add, let alone update my name. So my certificates are blank after completion.

2) No feedback tab available in-app to report issues.

3) Code languages are very error sensitive, yet there a lot of careless typos and mistakes in the lessons.

4) 3 hearts are insufficient for free users to be able to have a progressive learning experience, people are going to be tempted to look at the comments for solutions instead of actually learning when they have few chances to get them right. 

5) They aggressively push the pro feature on users ‚Äî I understand supporting the app, but there also young learners who don‚Äôt have that kind of money to just shell out. I get the advert for pro at least twice every time I open the app.

The only reason I put two stars is because I have managed to learn a thing or two through my courses, and there aren‚Äôt a lot of C# courses. Otherwise I would slap one star. The community involvement is the only thing keeping it a float ‚Äî there is a lot of room for improvement here. If Mimo had C# I wouldn‚Äôt be using this app.

review:
Tl;dr at the bottom. 

The app so far is great‚Äì it's beginner friendly and very step by step, and you're able to look at solutions for practices when you're stumped. There are comment sections on the lessons where you can find helpful information from other users. 

My only problems would be that the "challenge weapons" (what code you can use for special challenges) do not include Kotlin, which is the main language I am learning. Many of the solutions for practices do not include what the lesson taught (for example, the Kotlin practice example for filtering arrays does not use that command, instead going for forEach.) They do work of course, but it isn't helpful to see what you did wrong in implementing what you learned. 

A minor problem is there is no way to contact support within the app itself. There is an email and a way to do it through the site, but I would appreciate there being one in the app as well. I haven't contacted support for this due to forgetting my login information (the main reason I would like support within the app) so take it with a grain of salt as there might be a solution, but I bought the annual pro subscription and have not been able to access some of the features promised‚Äì the main one being seeing past errors in your practices rather than having them being locked. 

Tl;dr: Good app with a helpful community. Most issues I have with it are relatively minor, and I would definitely still recommend it. So far I wouldn't count the pro subscription as worth it, but you do you.

review:
You cannot restart a course which is a huge problem because you cannot review easily. I could care less about the point system.

My experience is with the python course(s) for the most basic things, the explanations are sufficient, but In my opinion, they don‚Äôt know how to teach in general. I study some psychology and am good at turning around and teaching things I learn. Many times the questions are confusing or try to get you solve something that hasn‚Äôt been explained well at all OR they intentionally make it so challenging that you basically are forced to give up and look at what other people are saying or look at the answer. I don‚Äôt have a problem with the right level of challenge because you grow from it, but if challenges are consistently too difficult, humans tend to give up (when you train a dog or a human baby, it is the same. Btw, usually the dog isn‚Äôt the problem. It is the trainer. Telling a dog they are a stupid idiot does nothing to make the dog better). About 3/4 of the topics, people in the comments explained the topic better than the app does.. I recently started watching bro code on YouTube. Much better. I was going to use this as a back up resource to refresh my memory of certain topics from a different perspective, but it is too much trouble.

review:

This took considerable time and effort, as not understanding the basics had me searching the web or forums for answers to the most basic things - and even the ones who wanted to help, I couldn‚Äôt give context into what I was doing as I wasn‚Äôt the one who wrote the code to begin with.

I‚Äôve tried learning from the roots, but everything out there was way too toddler style basic.  Even though I was a hack job of a programmer, I still had a good understanding of syntax.  When I found SoloLearn, and it‚Äôs community, I felt like I finally‚Ä¶FINALLY after all these years found a tool that teaches the basics but swiftly brings you up to intermediate and professional.  The coach challenges give great examples and practice as to how or why you would use what you just learned.  The community aspect is thriving and supports each individual lesson for those times you just can‚Äôt get it.  

SoloLearn is now a widget on my iOS Home Screen, it‚Äôs now the go to app whenever I have free time, and I absolutely love it.  Thank you so much.  Solo Pro was the best thing I ever did.  If you are a dreamer, looking for your own set of tools, this app will get you there - I promise.

review:

Unfortunately later you find out that the Code Playground is also only available in Pro after you get to use it for the first few lessons. Overall the app is very user friendly and well design but the paywall is limiting for those who don‚Äôt go Pro. I would prefer an ad-supported version with more features in Free or for them to just limit more lessons rather than take away the Code Playground. review:
You know how they give you free trials for a short period of time and you forget you even subscribed in the first place and now you‚Äôre $$$ less in your pocket? Well, letting that accident happen for me changed my direction in life.

I forgot about this $65 subscription (after tax) & after seeing it in my bank statement (but playing with the app for a couple days), i realized this was an investment, not a mistake. 

Sololearn has quickly grown to become one of my most used apps on my phone & it‚Äôs not because of the extensive library of courses, not because of the ability to create an account & save your progress, not because of the ability to add, train, and compete with your friends. It‚Äôs mostly due to the comment section feature that has been added to each section/page of each lesson! I love the extra little ‚Äòtips‚Äô everyone has & all the motivation they give each other. 

I‚Äôd say this app has made it to stardom in my eyes simply for the classroom aspect of it all. it sure makes it feel like i‚Äôm in a class setting, knowing that I can filter the comments by most recent if needed, having multiple Pro teachers within that comment section also helps in situations where you can‚Äôt understand the lesson. 

I never once wanted to code because of how complicated everything seemed, how expensive schools were, and how niche it felt. I can‚Äôt express enough how natural I feel learning how to program through an app! I would have never imagined. Now I‚Äôve downloaded xCode, followed YouTube coders, and even made learning how to code with Sololearn, a priority. 

Overall, this $5/m purchase that occurred on my device was ultimately one of the best accidental decisions of my life - hands down. 

Try the 7-Day, but you won‚Äôt regret it if you pay for the yearly either!

review:
Don‚Äôt trust the App Store Age Rating for this app. At the time of this review, it says ‚Äú4+‚Äù but the SoloLearn Terms of Use clearly state:

‚Äú if you are a child under thirteen (13), please do not attempt to register for or otherwise use the Services or send us any personal information.‚Äù

The Play Store via Android gives an ESRB rating of Teen (‚ÄúUsers interact.‚Äù) ‚ÄúContent is generally suitable for ages 13 and up. [...]‚Äù which is a much more accurate assessment of age-appropriateness.

The Age Rating these marketplaces assign to its apps are not the fault of the app developers, so given a (truer) target audience of 13+, I think this app deserves 4 stars.

- Features great concepts which never seem to reach their full potential, no matter how many revisions the UI/UX seems to endure

- Incentives structure (badges, XP, followers, popularity algorithms, etc.) continues to be problematic as an education app like this should emphasize and reward learning to code instead of simply indiscriminate increase in participation regardless of the kind of participation ... it can be very easy for younger learners to become engrossed in the non-coding related aspects of the platform

- Conscientious curriculum design is still a work-in-progress ... many courses still feel like the information provided is arbitrary, incomplete, and occasionally erroneous

- Division of subscription-based features vs free features also doesn‚Äôt make sense (seems arbitrary) with the exception of the subscription removing ads
title: Age Rating (@Parents)

review:
My daughter has been dying to learn to code since she read a few books on girls who code. 
So I downloaded the app this afternoon and she dove in. Admittedly I didn‚Äôt inspect the app thoroughly before allowing her to use it. Then my wife caught her conversing with adults, sharing personal info and was upset. 

I think it‚Äôs a good app. My daughter is smart. But allowing children to converse with adults all over the world is a recipe for disaster. 

There are some controls, and I‚Äôm usually pretty intuitive with technology, but simply adding a better offline mode (which seems to exist in the individual apps but not the all-inclusive one) or additional pw protected parental controls may be a better option. 

I looked through the settings and didn‚Äôt see those things, so if I‚Äôm missing something, let me know.

Update: Sololearn has informed me that they rate their app as 12+, Apple rates it as 4+.

review:
My computer‚Äôs been having issues lately, so being able to code on my iPad Pro has been very convenient. I‚Äôm a pretty novice programmer, so the tutorials for learning Java have helped me a lot. My favorite feature after the compiler is the challenges, which have helped me hone my skills and practice.

My only real complaint is that the Java compiler has a few bugs - less than other compilers I‚Äôve tried, and they don‚Äôt interfere too much in terms of running, but they can make the code look messy. Firstly, if you open a parenthesis or brackets, a second one pops up closing it (which is great), but deleting the first before typing anything doesn‚Äôt delete the second, and if you add another parenthesis to close out of habit, it just adds another parentheses. Also, tabbing sometimes produces inconsistent distances, or tabs on the wrong line. On a related note, the default template that appears when you start a new editor uses small tabs, but most times when you tab in the document, it makes a big tabs. One more bug is that if you hit enter and quickly start typing, it sometimes rearranged the letters you type. Undoing with control-z doesn‚Äôt work either. Sorry if I didn‚Äôt explain these well, I can explain better if you need! These are using the first iPad Pro with the Smart Keyboard, by the way. I know this probably isn‚Äôt your top priority to fix, but please do if you find an opportunity.

This is an amazing app, and I‚Äôm so lucky it exists, and for free too!

review:
SoloLearn is really good- you get tons of coding courses for free. I‚Äôve been using it for about two years now and it has rarely failed me. I recommend it first to anyone who asks me where they should learn to code. 

The Q&A is well-moderated and the courses are in good detail for the most part. The playground is a great place to test your code. All in all, Sololearn is a great tool if you want to test something really quick, or refer to a course if you are looking for quick information. This is especially useful when you have the app.

However, there are one or two problems I might report here in order that it gets fixed. In the mobile app, when you have the keyboard down in a code and click the < arrow button, it sees I havent saved the code and asks me to name it and save it. This is really useful, because without it I would have had too many projects lost because I never saved. However, it never prompts you if you have the keyboard up. For example, I was working on a project for over an hour on my mobile, and was expecting it to ask me to save when I pressed the < button (I had the keyboard up) and it never prompts me to save so all my progress was gone, which I was not expecting to happen. 

Also, some courses aren‚Äôt complete. The PHP course is missing a lot of important shadings revolving around opening and closing files.

I had spent long hard hours staring at a simple python program wondering why it wouldn‚Äôt work. It was a simple program: you input into one file, and the program puts the result in the output file. What would be an easy file error fix took me hours to troubleshoot (who knew that file.read() closes the file, resulting in errors if you want to read the file line by line?). Just these small tidbits of advice in the courses can save programmers lots of time.

review:
For my 400 level interaction design class, we‚Äôre required to review products customers interact with-here I go. 

Learning code is easy and fun through this app. Which now, is more ludic than the previous version because now users are encouraged to explore further into coding with featured games, a forum, and a coding platform (I think it‚Äôs IDLE) so that you may write your own code and save it. 

A complaint I have is that after getting a multiple choice question wrong, the answers are reshuffled. And in the heat of quickly realizing my mistake and wanting to quickly correct it to move on, I end up clicking on the wrong answer again because the answers were reshuffled a mere millisecond before I clicked on the right answer. I advise to remove the reshuffling since it‚Äôs frustrating and slows users down. 

Lastly, users want a responsive interaction. As for the drag and drop questions, it‚Äôs unclear to users whether or not the answer they‚Äôve ‚Äúpicked up‚Äù is to be dragged or dropped because nothing happens when you press your finger on it. The word picked should increase in size, or even better, shake. Users will find a shaking element familiar, as they do when they drag and drop apps on their phone‚Äôs home screen (#ohhh). 

Please leave a comment and let me know what you think of my usability ideas!

review:
I really appreciate what this app is trying to do, but there are a number of things that really bothered me about it when trying to learn C++ and test code snippets:

1. iOS‚Äô loupe is broken in the code editor.  It places the caret where your thumb is pressing, instead of the center of the magnifying glass, so you can‚Äôt see exactly where it will be located.  This is especially frustrating because...
2. The editor automatically adds closing parentheses, brackets, braces, and double quotes after the caret.  This is an infuriating ‚Äúfeature‚Äù that I turn off in every environment I use, and I haven‚Äôt found a way to turn it off here.  Because of this, I must relocate the caret on nearly every line, which when combined with item 1 makes this app completely useless as a mobile coding environment.

Regarding the lessons themselves.

3. I understand that c++ throws so much more at you than most other languages when you first step into it, and you want to simplify as much as you can, but I strongly disagree with how much the lessons insist upon the line "using namespace std;", which I've since learned is pretty widely agreed upon as bad practice.  Beginners should absolutely be exposed to using std::cout instead of cout in the global namespace, as it also serves as a handy reminder that the system header <iostream> needs to be included.

4. There needs to be a better way to skip modules.  By the time I installed this app, I was already familiar with most of what was covered in Module 1, and mostly needed to understand pointers and classes, but because I didn't know about prefix vs postfix increment/decrement operators and got one quiz question wrong, I had to trudge through 20+ quizzes consisting of "type "a" into this blank: __".

I would love to have an environment like this app to use my 2 hours of daily commute time learning and testing code, but my experience with c++ gives me the impression that other lessons on here will inculcate more bad habits I'll have to unlearn.

review: His app is awesome. It basically takes all the other SoloLearn apps and combined hem into one. Why download multiple apps for multiple languages when you can just get all the exact same lessons in one app! I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this for advanced programmers, but this is perfect for beginners who are just learning the ropes. This app even comes with it‚Äôs own coding engine so you can code in the app! If you are a teacher and only want to teach your students one language, then it makes sense to only have them get one of the other SoloLearn apps to make it simpler. But if you are just someone who wants to learn the ropes, then get this! It‚Äôs free, it‚Äôs awesome, and it‚Äôs never been easier to learn coding on the go. Perfect for people who don‚Äôt have much free time. I would recommend completing this course before going into other more advanced online courses. It also has a great, extremely helpful community. Even after you‚Äôve completed the course, there are still fun things to do such as the coding playground. Recently they added other lessons create by users which is great, and there are also coding challenges which are basically quizzes against other players. It‚Äôs also 100% free! No ads, no micro transactions, the whole package. So what are you waiting for? Anyone who is remotely interested in coding should get this app!

There are a ton of challenges that you can do in any language and the fact that is has a "code playground" where you can write your own code is incredible.

review: This is by far one of the best systems I've found for learning. The lessons are byte sized and they dont bore you with unnecessary details. The quizzes and challenges really help cement the concepts. But most importantly, theres a vast and active community with a comments section under every lesson page. So if you dont quite understand a concept, it's almost a guarantee that someone has explained it better in the comments section! Very rewarding way to learn at your own pace.

The best way to learn code is with a PC as you can use many different IDEs (Interactive Development Environments) to assist you, and, you can easily interact with your code. Smartphones are not that intuitive for typing - trust me, I coded a pythagorian triple calculator on my phone and it was tedious to say the least. Youtube is a good classroom.

review: I love this App. I have been working on programming for a little while and I finally started taking formal classes Thanks to this app, I have a lot of experience and I am learning that I already knew the majority of the skills. There are a few shortcomings: certain lessons such as the algorithm lesson are incomplete, that is to say, they don't present concrete examples of how to implement the algorithms which left me fairly confused. There also seems to be a stigma that beginners are capable of creating somewhat complicated programs such as the challenge to turn a string of a date into a date that references a day of the week. Even with all the formal lessons and Solo Learn lessons, so still can't figure out that one. While it's probably simple but it probably isn't incredibly simple.

review: NEW PROGRAMMERS BE WARNED - as an experienced programmer, I installed this app to review some quick Python basics. It was sad to see that not only are a lot of the lessons out of order, but also inaccurate. For example, the operator precedence lesson for Python indicates that all boolean operators have equal precedence, when in reality they do NOT have equal precedence (Sololearn, I challenge you to go check the Python documentation and compare it to the erroneous guide you all posted). From greatest to least greatest precedence, the boolean operators should be ordered as: Not, And, Or. Fortunately, there are public comments for every single slide, so a lot of confusion is mitigated via these, but overall I can probably point out at least 5 to 10 other spots where a beginner would get easily confused by these lessons. If you want to truly learn programming, grab yourself a real, physical book, with legit examples and thorough explanations. It really doesn't cost that much...you'll thank not just me, but yourself later. Please thumbs up this review so that others striving to learn programming make the first step in the right direction as well - a physical book with proper lessons, not these terribly ordered quick concept cards occasionally sprinkled with misleading information.
replyContent:
Thanks for your report.

The table in the lesson can indeed be confusing.
We have added a note to clarify the table.

We really appreciate your feedback and help in making SoloLearn an even better place for coders.

review: Sololearn is an app that is designed to help you learn various programming languages on your phone. Developed by Sololearn the app offers introduction lessons to the session that you‚Äôre working on, as well as a community forum for each problem. The learning style offers various techniques such as multiple choice and fill in the blank.   The design is very intuitive, offering the various languages, challenges and community Q&A right from the home screen. The app also offers achievement levels based on your completed challenges and activity in the forums. In addition to the navigation on the homescreen there is also a search function that allows you to see all of the topics based on your search criteria.   This is a great tool to get kids interested in programming in school. The flexibility of the mobile application means that any device can be used to teach you the basics. Also having the community tied into the lessons means that the teacher doesn‚Äôt have to be an expert on every language to have their students learn it! Though one drawback to the style is it is easy for a student to pass the lessons without fully learning the logic behind the code that they are using.
standardizedReview: sololearn app designed help learn various programming languages phone developed sololearn app offers introduction lessons session youre working well community forum problem learning style offers various techniques multiple choice fill blank design intuitive offering various languages challenges community qa right home screen app also offers achievement levels based completed challenges activity forums addition navigation homescreen also search function allows see topics based search criteria great tool get kids interested programming school flexibility mobile application means device used teach basics also community tied lessons means teacher doesnt expert every language students learn though one drawback style easy student pass lessons without fully learning logic behind code using

lessons. For example they teach you bootstrap 3 instead of the newer 
version, which again is fine but i would like to see a change. The element 
that made text blink is worthless so i think many of us agree that that 
lesson should be removed. Oh and most importantly, when you challenge 
someone and you get the problem incorrect after the challenge is over 
sololearn should teach you how to do it properly. Overall, i love 
sololearn. I have made many codes, and i have learned so much already :)

review:
SoloLearn has a strong focus on a few very basic syntactical elements of 
the introduced programming, scripting and markup languages as well as on 
simple workflow control in procedural programming. There are tons of 
useless comments to each and every page, often repeating the very same 
clear answer.. So this is rather a social platform / playground awarding 
the users' activities than a serious platform dwelling into some 
increasingly sophisticated conceptual / design challenges or techniques and 
principles of true software development.

Sololearn is one of the best apps for beginner developers to start with, 
and for experts to share their knowledge, ideas and codes in. It's a great 
place to meetup with other developers and gain more experience. A 
simplified and straightforward courses which can be learned offline; An 
online community with daily challenges, discussions, questions and answers; 
An advanced code playground for testing, saving and sharing codes. 
Personally, Sololearn had helped me to share my tremendeous love for 
programming with others. I was very happy using it, that's way I wrote this 
review even though I usually give only stars without writing a word. Hoping 
that Sololearn will help someone other there, as it helped me.

better! Beers for the lads and chocolate for the ladies involved :)

review: Easy to use, concepts are explained in just enough detail, the content is very well-edited and updated according to use feedback (unlike similar apps), and the community is very active.  The only negative is that the tests are perhaps too easy. It's virtually impossible to get questions wrong as the answers required are very basic and based from the previous page that you just saw. There is also no followup or revision testing as there is in Enki (though Solo Learn is superior in every other way).  It does make sense to have progression be simple and easy (it drives engagement and ensures people stick with the app/course - Duolingo does this extensively). At the same time, it'd be useful for opt-in testing (i.e. each course could have a fluency score which fades over time unless you "train" and do tests).

review: This app seems great at first.  I had to downgrade my rating for the following reasons.  1.  it appears that followers and upvotes are more important than learning.  2.  No real help is available because #1 discourages it with bad answers to get votes from followers.  3.  The course got confusing at the 75% point and I am not able to progress. 4. I bugs me constantly for all my contacts to be uploaded to their servers so it can spam them on my behalf, even after I have shared the app with the share button.  Due to the few poor choices made by the developer, the app is not a good tool for learning, especially for beginners. review: SoloLearn has been a great help for me, personally! Although there are a few irritants when trying to enter some of the brackets and the like on mobile, or trying to select a specific spot in the code prior, the benefits drastically outweigh the benefits. They offer a huge selection of languages and in bit-sized lesson form which can be perfect for if you only have a little bit of time at the moment. They also have a code playground which can be amazing for testing out what you're learning without the need for a computer at the ready - you can even post some works on the mobile to a community-driven collection that'll let others see and test out your works, too. Overall, it's offered a tonne of useful additions and lessons for students learning to program.

The quizzes at the end of each section are a joke too. They provide the answers in the question. I understand you can't write out code on your phone so they do little bits you have to fill in, but it'd be better if it were multiple choice showing 4 different sections of code and asking which is the best and explaining why it's the best. Some sections I learned nothing at all but I still got the right answer.

review: Challenges are garbage, except if you like to anwer slightly changed question 20 times in a row. Basically there are no moderation, so you will end up answering questions like: eval("!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!false") equals to true or false? And there are no way to flag any question for support to check or exclude.  There were questions I wanted to investigate further, but app does best for you not to - after time is out it automatically switches to next question, you cannot save it or pause challenge and it won't ask you if you are ready for next question nor give you opportunity to answer question just to check if you had right answer in mind. It does everything to make you don't care.  Also button to send answer is placed behind android keyboard, so if it hides accidentally you will end up with partial answer which is wrong.

review: This has to be one of the best apps available on the Google Play store. With SoloLearn, you can learn multiple computer languages straight from your phone! Their very own Code Playground let's you write code anywhere!   Similar to Duolingo, the lessons are structured in sections that you can take shortcuts to if you wish. Quizzes let you review past material and ensure that you retain what you learn. You can challenge other SoloLearners in 5-question programming quizzes for XP. A level system motivates you to keep learning and become the very best.  In addition to all of this, you can engage and talk directly with the community through the built-in forums! Here you can partake in coding challenges and ask programming-related questions, among other things.  If you're interested in learning how to program or want to become a better programmer, then I highly, HIGHLY recommend you download SoloLearn.

Plus, it's free and has no ads. :) Some users say that the explanations are lacking, but i think it is enough for newbies like me, especially because it does not make the lessons overwhelming or intimidating. So, thank you for making this!

review: A well done social network for programmers! The code playground is great for testing code on android. The small size of this program is a huge bonus as well. The comments on the tutorials are very helpful. However as far as learning different languages the tutorials could use some work. The examples are to short to few to grasp concepts without having to use other resources to understand them. Often times the answers they ask you after each tutorial can be completely unrelated to the current tutorial.  All of this review is based off completion of one language (Java). I will likely edit my review once I have more time with this app. Oh and before I forget the app asking me for a review several times before I finish a tutorial is slightly annoying. This may seem like a negative review but overall I must say I am very pleased with this app. I just wanted to give some positive criticism so hopefully some of these issues can be addressed.  7/3/17 - After a few months of using this app I felt like an update to my review was appropriate. Some of my previous issues with the app still apply most don't, for example it still asks me to review the app in the middle of tutorials. But that is such a minor annoyance compared to everything this app has taught me. The courses I talked about on my previous review about unrelated tutorial questions isn't so bad now since they keep adding new things to the tutorials and adding new tutorials too! With all that being said this app deserves more than the 5 stars I can give it. Thank you Sololearn for this amazing app and keep doing what your doing!

review: Love this app! Very well organized content, both in terms of how the notions are presented, and interactivity by inserting mini-tests throughout every chapter.  Important to mention here is the "try-it yourself" code module, which allows users to write their own code.  Then, the comments section, in which one can read other people opinions and write their own comments and questions. And the challenge-tests, they are both fun and instructive.  Then, I believe the "incentive" system with points, badges, etc is very well thought, to motivate the person who is learning. It is also very useful that it is one single app that integrates all the courses, instead of having separate apps for java, html, css etc. Though the level of the notions presented in these courses is far from being called advanced or comprehensive, the app does a very good job at initiating one in html, css, java, sql, etc. After one completes a course in SoloLearn, will be much easier to read and *understand* online documentation. In two words, this app makes learning fun, and keeps you motivated!

review: I love this app. Its an excellent learning tool. Especially when you're on the go. I gave this 3 stars due to the fact that I feel some things are not thoroughly explained and some of the choices for variable use in code examples can be incredibly confusing. I have put a great deal of time into the Python course which is excellent. (However, the Python course is the worst I have seen about confusing variables, for instance instead of showing or explaining where a var was assigned. And instead of using an obvious variable name like x or y, they will sometimes use a word that to the uneducated could easily be a function or module or who knows. Which leaves you setting staring at a small piece of code trying to figure where this new word came from what its purpose is.) I also started and almost finished HTML. I cant say I am as impressed with it. I feel most of it is not thoroughly explained. Most of the excercises and quizzes can be done without reading a single word of the course as they are all fill in the blank type questions that can easily be solved by just paying attention to the  opposite (opening or closing) tag. So even though I have completed a large majority of the course, I feel as though I have grasped only the basic idea behind HTML. I feel the HTML course really could use a redesign as its just not currently designed to make the information stick in your memory as a course on anything should be.   Something else I feel would be absolutely invaluable to this app is a way to see how code is executed and in what order. Just something that shows each step the execution goes through and lets you go back and forth at your own pace. This would be excellent for helping to understand the order of precedence as well as simply putting a lot of the example snippets into perspective rather than making you set there trying to work out a puzzle in your head. Something else that would also be invaluable  to this app is suggesting excercises that will coincide with each lesson and will require you to use things in that lesson multiple times. For instance create a guess the number game in Python when learning to use range as well as getting user input. Not only would suggesting excercises help thoroughly cement lessons in your memory, but they would also show where different things are needed/useful. Its very easy to find yourself wanting to overlook things because they dont seem immediately useful to you.  Hope this gets the attention of the devs. I want to give this 5 stars.. but it could be much better.

review: It's a great learning tool that has courses in many different coding languages, the courses are sensibly ordered, and, as far as I know, there is nothing you have to pay to use. In addition to the courses, it has challenges and things like that, along with an interface for making your own programs, of course. One little note, however; although the lessons tell you what you need to know and give examples, and they do have a question after every section, it doesn't assign big projects you have to build, so if you want to use what you've learned, you've just got to take it to the code editor. All in all a wonderful app, definitely worthy of five stars.

review: The examples on the site are often oversimplified, incomplete or just plain wrong.  It fosters a false sense of accomplishment.  The educational experience is reduced to a game in which you seek levels of experience to unlock badges.  It does not foster deep understanding of basic and vital concepts such as the importance of code hygeine for readability and maintainability.  The user-submitted challenges are often so poorly formatted or unrealistically convoluted that you run out of time trying to decipher them, but those who are rewarded care nothing about making quality code and haven't got a thorough understanding.  The examples and quizzes are far too trivial.  The comment sections are too short and with no character count to indicate when you exceeded size, so that when you submit 20 minutes worth of finger diddling your mobile device, it just drops your submission saying No Connection with no chance to go back and edit.  That said, the platform itself is designed well enough to deliver content of this nature.  But they need to develop more competent material and pedagogical technique, and cover meta-topics such as build systems, design patterns and code hygeine.  And de-emphasize or remove the game aspects.
standardizedReview: examples site often oversimplified incomplete plain wrong fosters false sense accomplishment educational experience reduced game seek levels experience unlock badges foster deep understanding basic vital concepts importance code hygeine readability maintainability usersubmitted challenges often poorly formatted unrealistically convoluted run time trying decipher rewarded care nothing making quality code havent got thorough understanding examples quizzes far trivial comment sections short character count indicate exceeded size submit 20 minutes worth finger diddling mobile device drops submission saying connection chance go back edit said platform designed well enough deliver content nature need develop competent material pedagogical technique cover metatopics build systems design patterns code hygeine deemphasize remove game aspects

review: Though the tutorials can hardly be considered as 'intensive' in any regard and topics are careened through with little-to-no elaboration, the overall effect is a rough yet practicable understanding by the user, enough to ideally incite further study and experimentation. Each slide is brief and they fluctuate wantonly between terribly simplified and unforgivingly vague, and the follow-up questions mostly either focus on unimportant minutiae (filler quizzes used to separate sections) or require completing overly-simple fill-in-the-blanks- and multiple-choice-type questions that offer next-to-zero genuine application, but though these lessons are the focus of each tutorial, the reasons I gave a 4 star review are the social network, challenge arena, help forums, code compiler, and example program library aspects, which are unique in the Android medium and themselves valuable.

review: Contains thorough tutorials for several coding languages. After you finish the tutorials, continue improving your skills by participating in user-written "challenges" against other users in order to collect badges. Tutorial lessons usually involve a short article on each structure followed by a short quiz. Experience points are earned by completing lessons and challenges and can be traded for hints and other shortcuts. There is no reference library in this app, although you can revisit tutorial material in any order after completion of that material.
